Kowtow Cleave and Iron Head are Kingambit's main attacks, heavily damaging defensive pivots like Corviknight, Hisuian Goodra, Scream Tail, and Garganacl. Sucker Punch lets it predict and punish faster attackers like Quaquaval, Volcarona, and Slither Wing that try and come in to revenge kill. 140 Speed EVs let Kingambit outspeed uninvested Corviknight and Skeledirge. Black Glasses lets Kingambit OHKO Iron Moth with Sucker Punch. Immunity abilities like Well-Baked Body and Earth Eater are options to pick up additional setup chances. Fast endgame sweepers like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Hisuian Electrode benefit from Kingambit's early-game presence, capitalizing on chipped foes and scoring easy KOs. Defensive pivots like Intimidate Corviknight, RegenVest Meloetta, and Fluffy Landorus-T can thwart revenge killers targeting Kingambit and use U-turn to bring it in safely again. Finally, Primordial Sea Zapdos can help Kingambit by forcing Corviknight and Quaquaval, two of its most consistent checks, letting it chip them on their switch-in repeatedly.

Physically Defensive.description: Great Tusk is a premier defensive wall thanks to its high physical bulk and access to utility such as Knock Off and Rapid Spin. Ice Spinner threatens Flying-type Pokemon like Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Dragonite. Bulk Up is used to boost Great Tusk's offensive and defensive presence, while Knock Off cripples switch-ins like Corviknight and Earth Eater Skeledirge. Regenerator provides reliable recovery and allows Great Tusk to switch back in to take hits from multiple threats, but Fluffy can be used to reduce damage taken from contact move users like Roaring Moon and physical Kommo-o. Leftovers can be used for small but valuable recovery, while Rocky Helmet can be used to punish contact attackers. Frailer Pokemon that are weak to entry hazards such as Azelf and Chien-Pao appreciate Great Tusk's ability to reliably remove hazards. Great Tusk's abysmal special bulk makes it susceptible to special attackers like Manaphy and Azelf. Therefore, Pokemon like Hisuian Goodra and RegenVest Manaphy can form a defensive core with Great Tusk, being able to switch into those wallbreakers and force them out with utility like Dragon Tail and Knock Off, respectively.

Offensive Bulk Up.description: A solid offensive typing, a high Attack stat, and wide coverage make Great Tusk a potent wallbreaker. Bulk Up is the main source of Great Tusk's power, increasing its tanking capabilities and offensive prowess. Great Tusk's typing and coverage allow it to set up in front of multiple physical attackers like Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Zamazenta-C. Ice Spinner OHKOes Primordial Sea Zapdos after a Bulk Up, OHKOes Dragonite and 2HKOes Landorus-Therian, while Knock Off threatens Skeledirge and Ceruledge if not running Headlong Rush and cripples defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Quaquaval, and Earth Eater Gholdengo looking to switch in. Close Combat threatens Earth Eater Kingambit and Empoleon, as well as Roaring Moon, while Headlong Rush threatens Iron Moth, Skeledirge and Ceruledge. Fluffy helps Great Tusk set up Bulk Up more easily with its heightened physical bulk, making it a powerful tank. Great Tusk is a potent wallbreaker and entry hazard remover, so Pokemon that are vulnerable to entry hazards like Ogerpon-H and Chien-Pao benefit from its presence. In return, they threaten common defensive Pokemon that wall Great Tusk, such as Manaphy and Corviknight. Great Tusk has terrible special bulk and appreciates pivoting, so special walls like RegenVest Roaring Moon and the aforementioned Manaphy make for great teammates. Despite Great Tusk's high Attack stat, it still requires entry hazard chip damage to pick up KOes, Stealth Rock to OHKO itemless Zapdos at +1 and Stealth Rock and three layers of Spikes to OHKO Toxapex. Therefore, teammates like Sandy Shocks and Garchomp, which can set up Stealth Rock and Spikes, are appreciated.

Choice Band.description: With a terrifyingly high Attack stat and access to strong STAB moves, Slither Wing stands out as a strong wallbreaker, being able to break through some of the tier's most common physical walls, including Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Quaquaval. First Impression is able to snipe common revenge killers, OHKOing the likes of Chien-Pao, Barraskewda, and all Ogerpon formes. Flare Blitz allows Slither Wing to hit Fluffy users like Zapdos and Great Tusk as well as non-Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, while Earthquake hits the likes of Ceruledge, Skeledirge, and Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, which otherwise resist or are immune to its moves. Sword of Ruin allows Slither Wing to safely 2HKO Corviknight and defensive Great Tusk with Close Combat, while Tinted Lens helps it OHKO offensive Zapdos with First Impression after slight chip damage and also deal solid damage against foes that resist Bug such as Dragonite and Great Tusk. Scrappy is a niche alternative that lets Slither Wing easily OHKO Gholdengo and Gengar and still 2HKO Corviknight. Slither Wing pairs well with fast cleaners like Chien-Pao and Barraskewda, as they can easily take over games after it has chipped down physically defensive walls like Corviknight, defensive Quaquaval, and Great Tusk. Slither Wing is fairly slow and susceptible to being OHKOed from the likes of Dragonite, Iron Moth, and Azelf, so defensive pivots like Corviknight and Manaphy are greatly appreciated, and they can also bring it in safely. Slither Wing also dislikes entry hazards, so hazard removal from the likes of Great Tusk or Corviknight is helpful, as this allows it to come in more often.

Hadron Engine.description: Sandy Shocks functions as a great offensive pivot thanks to its excellent offensive typing and ability to set entry hazards. Volt Switch lets Sandy Shocks pivot out of problematic matchups such as RegenVest Roaring Moon and Meloetta. Stealth Rock and Spikes allow Sandy Shocks to set up hazards against foes like Corviknight, Manaphy, and Zapdos, which are normally forced to switch out. Choice Scarf helps Sandy Shocks with its average Speed, turning it into a revenge killer and letting it outpace and OHKO other revenge killers like Barraskewda, Chien-Pao, and Iron Moth, while Heavy-Duty Boots lets it come in safely more often and also does not lock it into a move. Sandy Shocks forms great VoltTurn cores, so other offensive pivots such as Barraskewda, Meowscarada, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon are great teammates. Stronger wallbreakers like Walking Wake and Gengar appreciate Sandy Shocks's ability to chip down special walls such as Empoleon, RegenVest Manaphy, and Hisuian Goodra, which gives them an easier time breaking through these foes. Sandy Shocks is completely walled by the likes of Landorus, Iron Treads, and Volt Absorb Corviknight, so physical wallbreakers like Ogerpon-C and Chien-Pao are helpful in order to pressure them. Sandy Shocks is vulnerable to faster revenge killers like Barraskewda and Chien-Pao if it's not running Choice Scarf, meaning that defensive pivots like Corviknight and Manaphy are appreciated as well.

Immunity Ability.description: Immunity ability Sandy Shocks is a decent physical tank when it gets going due to its access to Iron Defense + Body Press and utility like Spikes. Iron Defense allows it to defend itself from common physical attackers like Great Tusk and Ogerpon-H, and Body Press threatens Electric-immune Pokemon like Volt Absorb Empoleon and Corviknight, as well as Motor Drive Manaphy. However, Spikes + Earth Power is an alternative to Iron Defense + Body Press, as it provides entry hazard utility and a secondary STAB move option. Substitute takes advantage of the free turns it can generate with its immunity ability and can block status from slower walls. Since Sandy Shocks doesn't have any form of reliable recovery, Leftovers is the preferred item. The ability choice comes down to team need; Earth Eater punishes Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Garchomp, while Water Absorb is an excellent check to Barraskewda and Zapdos that also can block pivoting from Empoleon. Sandy Shocks works well on hyper and bulky offense, as it can set up easier and can counter passive walls. Therefore, Pokemon that appreciate this ability like Chien-Pao and Dragonite make for good teammates. Despite its ability to increase its physical bulk, it is very vulnerable on the special side, making Pokemon like Gengar and Iron Moth threatening foes. Because of this, Pokemon like RegenVest Roaring Moon and Manaphy make for good teammates.

Ground Immunity.description: Iron Treads is an excellent spinner that is able to switch into common entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Landorus-T with its own Levitate while also being able to use Knock Off on common switch-ins such as Corviknight. Iron Treads can opt to be a hazard setter itself with Stealth Rock, keep up momentum with Volt Switch on targets like Corviknight, or use Heavy Slam as a strong STAB option for Scream Tail and Chien-Pao. Levitate allows Iron Treads to be immune to Spikes while also being able to spin them away, whereas Earth Eater can be used as an alternative for better longevity against hazard setters like Garchomp and Smack Down Landorus-T. Offensive Pokemon that are weak to hazards such as Chien-Pao and Thundurus-T appreciate Iron Treads's ability to keep hazards off the field, as well as being able to pivot them in safely with Volt Switch. Strong physical attackers like Galarian Zapdos and Kingambit also are good teammates for Iron Treads, as they can more easily break through Corviknight with Knock Off support from Iron Treads. Iron Treads can be overwhelmed by coverage options from hazard setters such as Liquidation Garchomp, so running Wish Scream Tail, which can increase Iron Treads's longevity, or a secondary hazard remover like Corviknight and Quaquaval, which can also stave off hits, is recommended. Iron Treads is also vulnerable to strong Fighting-type attackers such as Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing, so it is advised to pair it with a Fighting-resistant teammate such as Scream Tail or Fluffy Zapdos.

Fire Immunity.description: Well-Baked Body Iron Treads is a spinner with a great defensive typing in addition to a Fire immunity and ability to compress several roles such as item and entry hazard removal into one Pokemon. It is notably able to threaten the tier's premier spinblocker in Skeledirge, allowing it to remove hazards freely. If there is already a Stealth Rock user on the team, Iron Treads can instead use Heavy Slam to check Calm Mind Scream Tail and Enamorus-T, Rock Slide to OHKO Talonflame and Volcarona, or Volt Switch to bring in teammates safely. 236 Speed EVs are used to outspeed and threaten an OHKO on Jolly Hisuian Arcanine. Pixilate Scream Tail and Primordial Sea users like Inteleon, Greninja, and Quaquaval all appreciate Iron Treads switching into their checks in Desolate Land Fire-types like Iron Moth and Ceruledge. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Hisuian Arcanine appreciate Iron Treads removing items from shared switch-ins like Corviknight and Quaquaval. Fighting- and Ground- types like Galarian Zapdos, Slither Wing, and Garchomp threaten Iron Treads, so defensive partners like Scream Tail, Quaquaval, and Corviknight are recommended. Iron Treads's Rapid Spin also supports the hazard stacking effort from partners like Garchomp and Ting-Lu. Certain Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge can still threaten Iron Treads with their coverage moves, so it appreciates a secondary check to them like Primordial Sea Zapdos.

Sheer Force.description: With high-Base Power moves and decent Special Attack and Speed, Iron Jugulis is a solid wallbreaker that can outspeed and threaten common specially defensive foes, like Garchomp and Garganacl. Iron Jugulis offers a notable niche, as Hurricane + Dark Pulse + Focus Blast can hit every viable Pokemon for neutral damage. Taunt disrupts attempts to heal, set up, or set entry hazards, allowing Iron Jugulis to better handle Pokemon such as Blissey and Clodsire. Iron Jugulis struggles against special walls like Florges and Scream Tail, so physically offensive teammates like Cinderace and Ceruledge are necessary to break through them. Due to its frailty, it enjoys teammates like Slither Wing and Corviknight that can pivot it in, the latter of which can also remove hazards with Defog. Iron Jugulis also appreciates entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu, which can enable it to secure KOs that it would typically miss, such as Garganacl.

Magic Guard.description: Magic Guard Gholdengo is an extremely powerful special wallbreaker that takes advantage of Nasty Plot, Life Orb, and Steel Beam, the latter two without recoil, to overwhelm special walls. Shadow Ball provides excellent neutral coverage, hitting Manaphy, Hisuian Goodra, and Empoleon. Hex is an alternative with Toxic Spikes or other status support and bypasses Bulletproof. Recover gives Gholdengo the ability to heal off damage taken while setting up, as well as simply giving it the longevity to attack the opponent's team throughout the battle. Alternatively, Focus Blast hits Steel-types like Heatran and Hisuian Goodra, while Thunder Wave slows down faster attackers like Iron Moth and Roaring Moon that try to threaten Gholdengo while powering up Hex to break down bulkier Pokemon like Manaphy. Gholdengo's ability to beat down balanced cores with the sheer strength of Steel Beam benefits faster cleaners like Barraskewda, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf Azelf and Walking Wake. If Gholdengo runs Thunder Wave, it can also support other offensive Pokemon that appreciate faster attackers getting slowed down, such as Great Tusk, Ceruledge, and Dragonite. However, Gholdengo is vulnerable to faster Dark-types like Chien-Pao, so Pokemon that can check them like Corviknight and Quaquaval are appreciated. Corviknight can even safely bring in Gholdengo with its U-turn. Additionally, if Gholdengo is not using Thunder Wave and Hex, RegenVest users like Manaphy and Meloetta completely wall it, so Pokemon that beat them with super effective STAB moves or physical attacks like Desolate Land Ogerpon-H and Roaring Moon are appreciated.

Offensive.description: With Nasty Plot, a fantastic offensive and defensive typing, and solid coverage, Gholdengo is a terrifying wallbreaker that threatens to tear apart teams after a single free turn. Hex can be used over Shadow Ball with Thunder Wave or Toxic Spikes support, with Life Orb sets 2HKOing badly poisoned RegenVest Manaphy while also threatening Bulletproof Gholdengo. Recover gives Gholdengo significant longevity and multiple opportunities to use Nasty Plot, while Substitute gives it a free turn to set up Nasty Plot or Thunder Wave against foes like Corviknight and Kommo-o and dodges phazing attempts from Dragon Tail users like Hisuian Goodra and Roaring Moon. Focus Blast hits Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Hisuian Goodra, while Thunder Wave can boost the power of Hex and spread useful paralysis against threats like Manaphy, Roaring Moon, and Ogerpon-C. Leftovers and Colbur Berry both boost its longevity, with the latter letting Gholdengo survive Knock Off from Roaring Moon or +2 Ogerpon-C, while Life Orb boosts Gholdengo's power significantly, granting it feats such as guaranteeing a 2HKO on specially defensive Garchomp with Make It Rain. If running Focus Blast, Beads of Ruin is an option over Adaptability, boosting Focus Blast's power at the cost of revealing Gholdengo's ability and slightly decreasing the power of its STAB moves. Gholdengo can struggle to break through common special walls like Blissey, Bulletproof Empoleon, and RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta, so it appreciates powerful offensive teammates like Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-C, and Galarian Zapdos that can handle these walls while Gholdengo picks off physical walls like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Kommo-o. Gholdengo appreciates defensive pivots like Corviknight, Manaphy, and Empoleon that can take a hit and bring Gholdengo in against foes it forces out such as Kommo-o, Pixilate Scream Tail, and Galarian Zapdos.

Specially Defensive.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Earth Eater Kingambit, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Talonflame and Quaquaval. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail and Lucario can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Corviknight is a good teammate that also provides Defog.

RegenVest Wall.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Hydreigon and Iron Moth. Throat Chop provides STAB damage and lets it beat Boomburst users, Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon and Blissey. Some special attackers like Scream Tail can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options. Ting-Lu can switch into weaker physical attackers like Roaring Moon, but it should be used as help for the main physical wall on the team. Ting-Lu is vulnerable to opposing setup sweepers, so teammates like Unaware Corviknight are greatly appreciated. Corviknight can also reduce Ting-Lu's weakness to entry hazards.

Choice Item Attacker.description: Chi-Yu's strong base stats and excellent STAB coverage make it a flexible offensive threat. Choice Specs provides maximum wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to OHKO physically defensive Ting-Lu with Desolate Land + Overheat, whereas Choice Scarf gives it the Speed to clean late-game and chase out faster threats like Cinderace and Chien-Pao. Desolate Land provides the most damage amplification and comes with an immunity to Water, whereas No Guard enables Chi-Yu to liberally spread burns with Inferno. Psychic is useful coverage to hit Clodsire and Iron Moth super effectively; alternatively, Will-O-Wisp allows Desolate Land sets to reliably spread burn, however Chi-Yu's poor bulk means it can be dangerous to use. Chi-Yu's best fit is on balance and offense teams that appreciate its high damage output, as well as its good matchups against common special walls like RegenVest Iron Treads. Bulky pivots, like the aforementioned Corviknight and Iron Treads, make particularly good Chi-Yu partners because both can clear entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock.

Nasty Plot.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack and decent Speed, Chi-Yu is a potent wallbreaker that makes use of Nasty Plot and its unresisted STAB combination to tear through common walls like Sand Stream Garganacl and non-Unaware Florges. Chi-Yu generally prefers to run Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid entry hazard damage, but Life Orb can be run on Sheer Force sets for extra power. Chi-Yu also has several Fire-type STAB moves to choose from: Fire Blast is the most powerful, Flamethrower is the most consistent option, and Inferno is used on No Guard sets to punish switch-ins like Garganacl and Ting-Lu with a burn. Chi-Yu does struggle against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey, so physically offensive Pokemon like Meowscarada and Kingambit make good teammates. Chi-Yu is also physically frail, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Avalugg that can switch into strong physical attacks and Wish passers like Florges and Scream Tail that can help it stay healthy.

RegenVest.description: Roaring Moon is an excellent user of RegenVest with a typing that plays well into the tier's special setup sweepers and pivots like Iron Moth, Sandy Shocks, and all variants of Zapdos. Knock Off cripples switch-ins like Great Tusk and Corviknight while also threatening a 2HKO on offensive Gholdengo and an OHKO on Gengar and Azelf. U-turn allows Roaring Moon to pivot out on these switch-ins, and Dragon Tail allows Roaring Moon to force out setup sweepers such as Manaphy, which Roaring Moon cannot meaningfully damage, while letting it rack up entry hazard damage. Stone Edge allows Roaring Moon to threaten the plethora of Flying- and Fire-types that the tier has, such as Thundurus, Iron Moth, and Zapdos, while Iron Head allows it to chip Fairy-types like Scream Tail and Diancie that otherwise can switch in freely. Roaring Moon appreciates physically defensive walls like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Quaquaval that can remove entry hazards which limit Roaring Moon's walling capabilities, while it checks the special Electric- and Fire-types that threaten them like Hisuian Electrode and Iron Moth in return. Roaring Moon's presence is appreciated by pivots and wallbreakers like Galarian Zapdos and Sword of Ruin Ceruledge due to its ability to switch into revenge killing attempts from the likes of Hisuian Electrode, Sandy Shocks, and Azelf. Roaring Moon deathly fears Dragon- and Fairy-types like Hydreigon, Walking Wake, and Enamorus-T, making Earth Eater Empoleon a notable partner with its ability to pivot into these Pokemon.

Swords Dance.description: Ogerpon-H is a strong wallbreaker that is able to beat many of the tier's premier walls, such as Corviknight, Scream Tail, and Great Tusk thanks to its high Attack, excellent STAB moves, and good Speed tier. Power Whip can be used to get massive damage on Ground- and Water-types, including securing the KO on Intimidate Quaquaval and physically defensive Great Tusk after Swords Dance, while Horn Leech can be run instead to give Ogerpon-H more longevity. Ogerpon-H has a number of options for its last moveslot, such as Play Rough to hit Kommo-o and Roaring Moon, OHKOing both after a Swords Dance, and Knock Off to cripple foes, especially switch-ins like Primordial Sea Zapdos, which gets 2HKOed after Stealth Rock, as well as 2HKOing Well-Baked Body Gholdengo with Sword of Ruin. Desolate Land provides the most power to Ivy Cudgel and lets Ogerpon-H offensively check Water-types like Manaphy and Barraskewda, while Sword of Ruin allows Play Rough to OHKO Kommo-o and 2HKO Garchomp. Due to its average defenses and lack of recovery if not running Horn Leech, Ogerpon-H benefits both from entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Quaquaval and slow pivots like Corviknight and Empoleon that can get it on the field safely. Ogerpon-H also appreciates hazard setters like Garchomp and Heatran, which can chip down walls like Scream Tail for it to more easily KO.

Ogerpon-C, with the combination of Swords Dance + Ivy Cudgel that is further boosted by Rocky Payload and its signature item Cornerstone Mask, is a devastating physical wallbreaker that is able to threaten common physical walls in Corviknight, Zapdos, Great Tusk, and defensive Quaquaval. Power Whip is a more powerful Grass-type STAB move, while Horn Leech is more reliable and provides better longevity. Knock Off hits Gholdengo and wears down Corviknight, Play Rough 2HKOes defensive Kommo-o and chips Sap Sipper Great Tusk, while Trailblaze is an option to make Ogerpon-C a potential sweeping threat. Fast physical attackers like Barraskewda, Roaring Moon, and Meowscarda appreciate Ogerpon-C being able to apply constant offensive pressure to help break down Corviknight, Zapdos, and if running Play Rough, Kommo-o, allowing them to be more efficient cleaners. Ogerpon-C has a poor defensive typing and can be vulnerable to chip damage or entry hazards, thus slow pivots like Corviknight, which can remove hazards, and Manaphy, on balance or more offensive-oriented dual screens teams, are recommended so that Ogerpon-C can come in safely. Ogerpon-C is also vulnerable to faster offensive Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Barraskewda, so speed control like Choice Scarf Azelf and Roaring Moon are also good teammates for it.
